i have a few suggestions about that if there should be a new system then how it should be like :
 
1).      punishment on the basis of level of toxicity in one game instead of giving them 10 chances to get away with their negative behavior . 

2) .      request of taking away the right to report anyone ( misuse of the report system ) category should be added to the report options .

3) .     An in game warning system . warning the player that he needs to watch his behavior and stay cool cause they are exceeding the levels of negativity . and warning them that they will be punished . give this warning 2 or 3 times and then punish them before the end of the match if possible or right after the match .

4 ) .  there should be negative behavior levels scaling 1-10 for every single match . similarly for good behavior for every single match they should be rewarded later .

6) . a separate category for the players who harass others in a group form ( basically protecting the rights of the solo players ) .  the punishment for this should be more severe than other categories .

7) .  a warning system in and out of the game constantly reminding the negative ones to watch their behavior .  similarly a message of goodwill to the good ones encouraging them to help end fights in game acting like moderators .( they can even give them the title ) the real chill dudes :) .

9) . there can also be a message from the management when the fight actually starts telling both parties that they need to cool it and that its a team game and that for winning its important that they should work together .

10) . this one is  optional  . there should be punishments like taking away some of the ip or blocking some champ skins or champions . or blocking their hextech loot access or  making them wait in every que for 2-5 mins showing the cause of the punishment . or blocking their access to some of the items . basically there should be small but effective punishments reminding them of their behavior and forcing them to be nice to others .

I'll have to disagree with you in regards to majority think like you that "innocent people are getting punished while the toxic get away scott free".

Your opinion actually comes from a lack of understanding on the system, where it does a good job at catching toxicity. Where you misunderstand it is that it does a horrible job in letting you know someone got punished.

Currently, the system just notifies you that someone got punished if the game you reported them in was the game that you reported them in.  If they get punished the next game (or down the road), you'll never know.

This indeed makes people feel the system doesn't exist (cos they never "see it in action), and some people think you can do whatever with it and never get punished. Mean while, there are others that think people are getting away with toxicity and the system does nothing.

Then there are also people (like me) that understand the system a whole lot, and know what is punishable and what isn't. When people threaten to report me, I really have no fear cos I know I haven't done anything wrong thus won't get punished by the system.

Both instances, this can be solved by increasing the system's visibility. Riot is aware of this problem, but they currently have other priorities such as finishing the new client. The next thing that comes is the new honor system. Maybe after that we'll be getting tools to increase behavioral visibility like [this](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/aFmEtAVK-riot-should-add-monthly-status-cards).

> you tell me that what is more offensive ? targeting one person in the team or complaining to those people about toxicity .

hmm .. that is actually a wrong argument in the context of Riot's behavioral system. It would be the proper argument if it was like a court system and said "this is the game, a bunch of these are toxics, this guy is just defending himself, therefore we should punish these other guys and not the dude defending himself".

However, the behavioral system doesn't work like that. It takes in account for your toxicity history alone (and no one else's) and when it passes a certain threshold, it deals punishment. 

For example (note, numbers are hypothetical):

* Each game you are (validly) reported, the system marks you on a toxicity scale of 1-10, where 1 is small stuff like calling for reports / gg ez and 10 is hate speech / homophobia
* it takes 25 points to get yourself punished
* if you played 25 games and asked for reports every game, then you'll get punished.
* If you played 3 games with hate speech you get punished.

They can be at 1 point, use hate speech and they'll be at 11 points. Whereas if you were at 24 points and asked for reports, BAM, you'll get punished (and also feeling that they got off scott free). 

So with the example above, you'll see that people are punished for their own history and how offensive other's speech will be irrelevant to your own punishment. 

Also, multiple reports within the same game don't get people punished faster.

Imagine discussing how to improve the concept of a car with somebody.
Now imagine that person would keep on pointing out flaws like "Square tires will never work" and "Putting water in the tank is a horrible idea".
Now imagine trying to explain to that person in all possible ways that the tires are round and that you are putting gas in the tank.
And now, finally, imagine that person then simply waves their hand and goes "Naaaah... I know what's going on. Those are square tires and you're putting water in the tank."

That's not a constructive discussion. If **you** wanna talk about the improvement of the system, you should first actually try to understand how the system works, rather than just going with your first theory of how it works and ignoring every input from people that disagree with you.

That's why people keep discussing how the system works with you. To get to common ground so both parties have the same picture of how the system works **currently**. This isn't about who to believe. They system has the capability to verify whether those reports are valid, so if a guy is spamming reports for no reason then the system will just mark his reports as "false" and not contribute to someone else's punishment points.

Just because 5 people reported that person, the amount of points which the person gets for that game doesn't change. 

If both people are at fault, the system will allocate the necessary points to both. One of them may get more points than the other, but we'll never know how many points one gets  for different types of toxicity (other than we know that kys / hate speech / homophobia racks up points alot faster than anything else).

cos the system's learning capability is based on what we report and what we as a community deem inappropriate. Riot has some soft rules, but ultimately, we are the ones that decide what isn't acceptable.

* You only need _one_ report to flag another player

* More reports _are not validated_ by Riot's system

* Calling for reports _does not mean someone is more likely to be punished_, anything more than 1 report is discarded and does not "weigh more" to Riot

* If someone is being toxic to you or someone else, mute them, report them endgame and move on. There is no such thing in League as "fighting fire with fire", etc -- you're only adding to the negative environment by arguing with a troll/toxic person

This is another location where the behavioral system is lacking. They don't show the full punishment history. 

They just show you 1 "recent" game as an example. We don't know what "recent" stands for, but if you don't play the game often, then you'll more likely just get 1 game shown to you. 

If you were able to see your whole report card, it'll probably say something like "you were validly reported 30 times in the past 100 games." or something like that.

If you had previous restrictions/penalties, then yes continuously arguing with trolls/flamers will get _you_ punished as well.

If you were using hate speech such as racial or homophobic slurs, that can escalate you instantly to a permaban.

When someone retaliates to toxicity by being toxic, they become part of the problem. It doesn't matter whose toxicity was "worse." Both of the toxic people need to change their behavior, and both have earned the consequences of their actions.

>im making the situation worse or you are by blaming the one whose already the victim lmao . 

If I were blaming the victim, I'd be telling you it is your fault for getting flamed in the first place. I have said no such thing. It's unfortunate to be attacked by someone when you're just trying to play a video game, and you have every right to defend yourself **by muting and reporting**.

Where you are at fault is in **retaliating**. That's not okay.

Think about it this way: if you are in a grocery store, and someone starts an argument with you and calls you names, you are a victim of toxicity. If you respond by screaming obscenities and hate speech, then you are making the problem worse and not better, and now everyone within earshot is a victim of your toxicity, because they just wanted to shop in peace.

It's a team game and you're matched with nine strangers. Even if it was okay to lash out at someone who insulted you first (it's not, but I accept that you think it is), you have to remember that there are a bunch of other people in the game, and by retaliating you're making the toxic situation worse, drawing it out, and creating more unpleasantness for the innocent bystanders. Those people are also victims, and for them you were one of the perpetrators.
